awd_titl_txt: Rural Girls Engaged in Math and Science Plus Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging in hands-on field experience, laboratory/project-based entrepreneurship tasks and mentorship experiences.  This Hinds Community College project will involve junior and senior high school girls from four high schools from three Mississippi rural counties--Copiah, Claiborne, and Hinds--to participate in a summer apprenticeship program and other activities to increase their awareness about STEM and academic preparedness for a pathway to STEM related careers. The program will last three years and will engage up to 120 rising high school junior and senior female students intensively and introduce up to 300 female students to STEM education and careers. During the three year grant period, the project will implement the following activities: a four-week summer apprenticeship with a near-peer mentoring program; host an annual STEM Girls Rock Convocation; offer Spring Break STEM Tours for apprentices, their parents/caregivers and mentors, and Hinds Community College STEM instructors; offer after-school and Saturday science fair project assistance; and collaborate with the Shodor Foundation, a nonprofit research and education organization and a national resource for computational science education, to offer workshops for high school teachers, counselors and administrators.

The primary focus of the proposed project is to grow the pipeline of female students who are aware of STEM and computer science educational pathways and career opportunities. The goals of the project are to: 1) Provide evidence of engaging minority females in hands-on experiences in STEM-related technologies and practices; 2) Document evidence of advancing knowledge on how best to prepare minority females for STEM-related occupations; and 3) Build and expand the research foundation on STEM learning and learning environments, workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The project includes an infrastructure mechanism for teachers and administrators within the high school to support students by providing them opportunities to build their academic skills while participating in the project. A concurrent mixed methods research design will be used that combines quantitative and qualitative approaches to assess the latent variables.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Hinds Community College - Utica Campus (HCC-UC) project R-GEMS+T (Rural Girls Engaged in Mathematics and Science Plus Technology) has been cultivating female high school students of color to study in STEM-related fields after high school and explore STEM careers, particularly in the technology sector with technology-rich experiences that develop disciplinary knowledge, practices, and 21st-century skills for any occupation. 

At the beginning of year two (2) academic year, HCC-UC had its second annual Fall STEM Girls Rock Convocation, dubbed STEM Girls RockFall 2019 Assembly and Symposium, as one of their premier female-focus projects. The plenary sessions involved inspirational talks from successful STEM practitioners; showcased hands-on lab activities; face-to-face interactions with representatives from colleges and universities, advanced manufacturing and information technology industries, the armed forces, and STEM enrichment programs. The 2nd year convened 156 students, and subsequent years convened up to 200+ participants. During the pandemic, there was a temporary pause in the face-to-face and group program delivery of services.  The overall number of participants was reduced but not the quality of program delivery to participants. The College adjusted by incorporating online Learning Management Systems: ZOOM, Teams, Google, etc., for meetings. Some of the limitations include the following:

  • COVID-19 restrictions limited student recruitment and engagement
  • Orders for equipment and supplies are backlogged due to availability and transportation issues
  • Venues usually available for summer tours and enrichment activities were closed or had limited access.
  • Limited Wi-Fi connections and internet access to technology hampered communications and impacted the overall operations of the Upward Bounds Programs.

School districts shared information about the program via flyers, websites, and social media platforms; announced and promoted the science fair, mentoring assistance, summer apprenticeship, and the annual STEM Girls Rock Symposium; and via conference proposals to local, state, and national organizations. RGEMS+T continued to build on the usage of near-peer mentoring for girls (Sisters in STEM program) and has extended its ambassadors? network.

As a result of this program, other disciplines experience student interest in the transference of skills attained to non-STEM courses like Humanities, Arts, Literature, and Management. Many high schools lack science fair events and projects; because of this project, they have been willing to allow students to participate in and conduct such activities. RGEMS+T activities have increased students' knowledge of STEM and created a desire to pursue STEM degrees and career paths. Other programs on campus (i.e., Upward Bound, Upward Bound Math and Science, and Student Support Services) have inquired about implementing more STEM curricula to enhance their program effectiveness.

A significant impact of RGEMS+T beyond HCC-UC has been the ability to leverage, build and maintain solid relationships/collaborations with high schools, 4-year institutions, and STEM businesses and industries, which will enhance learning for potential STEM students, teachers, and faculty. The apprenticeship model of the project builds long-term relationships between participants, mentors, graduates, and former participants who were encouraged to serve on panels and as mentors. Strong STEM programs at the community college level will impact minority female students county-wide and serve as a model for the state. Two-year colleges are not known for scientific research; therefore, the project will serve as a national model for other community colleges? MSIs to encourage student matriculation from high school to community college and to 4-year institutions. It is anticipated that project staff will present results at local, state, and national STEM conferences, and peer-reviewed publications will be submitted to journals.

Intellectual Merit Statement. The design of activities draws on previously cited research literature in the initial proposal that documents and supports the effectiveness of activities as well as HCC-UC past experiences and knowledge gained from similar NSF project results.

Activities were implemented, and evaluation and satisfaction surveys were conducted to determine whether adjustments were warranted or continuance with ongoing activities ?as-is? was the direction to go. The four areas listed below were critical in determining program success. 

(1)    Emphasis on STEM and computational science education

(2)    Participant?s exposure and access to state-of-the-art technological tools and hands-on problem-based experiences

(3)    Exposure and Engagements with Partnerships in higher education institutions and businesses, and

(4)    Classroom, field-based experiences that serve to increase interest in STEM-related fields and occupations

The first four (4) years of the program yielded outstanding results. Year five (5) of the program proved challenging (due to COVID limitations), directly affecting the number of participants. Students who received STEM education via focused summer activities and were exposed to technological tools that stirred their interest in participating in hands-on, problem-based activities began to see that they could build and program robotics and that math and science was fun. They saw themselves moving to four (4) year institutions and as employees of corporations. Lastly, the classroom, field-based, and mentoring experiences helped to build their confidence which assured them that they have what it takes to participate successfully in STEM-based higher education programs.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2022
Modified by: Jonathan W Townes

Image
  • R-GEMS+T (Rural Girls Engaged in Mathematics and Science Plus Technology has cultivated interest among female HS students of color to study STEMrelated fields in HS, providing exposure to STEM careers, especially in the technology sector.
    This work is supported by the National Science Foundation under RGEMS+T (Award No. 1657174). This report was completed by MN Associates, Inc.
    Public Domain
    Jonathan W Townes
    RGEMS+T Yr4 Eval Rpt Revised-Image

MSIs to encourage student matriculation from high school to community college and to 4-year institutions. Lastly, the classroom, field-based, and mentoring experiences helped to build their confidence which assured them that they have what it takes to participate successfully in STEM-based higher education programs.
